title: My Lab Journal
text:
This is the Lab Journal of Lucas Rousselange for the CDSfBA course in the WiSe2024.

[Status]: [ 70%]

title: Instrumental Variables
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
Code
#Load data set and libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(jtools)
library(kableExtra)
library(MatchIt)
membership <- readRDS("../../../Causal_Data_Science_Data/membership.rds")

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
Exploring the relationships
Plotting a heat map for the available factors, there seems to be a high correlation between age, average purchase and pre membership average purchase.The pre membership average purchase, age and membership card also seem correlated. The sex seems to not have a big influence on either variable.


Code
mem_cor <- as.data.frame(cor(membership))
mem_heat <- mem_cor %>%
  rownames_to_column() %>%
  gather(colname, value, -rowname)

ggplot(mem_heat, aes(x=colname,y=rowname, fill=value)) + 
  geom_tile(color='black')+
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = 'blue4')+
  geom_text(aes(label = round(value,2)), color = "black", size = 4) +
  labs(x='', y='', title = 'Heatmap correlation between variables')

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
DAG


Code
# Confounder
confounding <- dagify(
  X ~ Z1,
  Y ~ Z1,
  Y ~ X,
  X ~ Z2,
  Y ~ Z2,
  Z2 ~ Z1,
  coords = list(x = c(Y = 3, Z1 = 1, X = 1, Z2=3),
                y = c(Y = 0, Z1 = 1, X = 0, Z2 =1)),
  labels = list(Z2 = "pre_avg_purch",
                Y = "avg_purch",
                Z1 = "age",
                X= 'card')
  )


p <- ggdag(confounding) +
  geom_dag_point(color = "#15c1d4") +
  geom_dag_text(color = "white") +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "black") +
  geom_dag_label_repel(aes(label = label))+
  theme_dag_blank()
p

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
(Coarsened) Exact Matching:


Code
cem <- matchit(card ~ age + pre_avg_purch,
               data = membership, 
               method = 'cem', 
               estimand = 'ATE')
summary(cem)


#> 
#> Call:
#> matchit(formula = card ~ age + pre_avg_purch, data = membership, 
#>     method = "cem", estimand = "ATE")
#> 
#> Summary of Balance for All Data:
#>               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
#> age                 42.0331       39.1574          0.2136     1.1524    0.0438
#> pre_avg_purch       76.3938       66.0438          0.3962     1.0276    0.1092
#>               eCDF Max
#> age             0.0864
#> pre_avg_purch   0.1545
#> 
#> Summary of Balance for Matched Data:
#>               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
#> age                 40.2869       40.2645          0.0017     1.0001    0.0016
#> pre_avg_purch       70.5402       70.1875          0.0135     0.9910    0.0044
#>               eCDF Max Std. Pair Dist.
#> age             0.0067          0.1224

#> Matched (ESS) 5527.11 3928.04

#> Unmatched       16.     33.  
#> Discarded        0.      0.

df_cem <- match.data(cem)
lm_cem <- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
summ(lm_cem)

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
Nearest-Neighbor Matching:


Code
nn <- matchit(card ~ age + pre_avg_purch,
               data = membership, 
               method = 'cem', 
               estimand = 'ATE')
summary(nn)


#>

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
Inverse Probability Weighting:


Code
# (1) Propensity scores
model_prop <- glm(card ~ age + pre_avg_purch,
                  data = membership,
                  family = binomial(link = "logit"))
summary(model_prop)


#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = card ~ age + pre_avg_purch, family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
#>     data = membership)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                 Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)   -1.4121735  0.0723729 -19.512   <2e-16 ***
#> age            0.0011734  0.0017758   0.661    0.509    
#> pre_avg_purch  0.0148181  0.0009263  15.996   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 13626  on 9999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 13250  on 9997  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 13256
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4


Code
# Add propensities to table
membership_aug <- membership %>% mutate(propensity = predict(model_prop, type = "response"))

# Extend data by IPW scores
membership_ipw <- membership_aug %>% mutate(
  ipw = (card/propensity) + ((1-card) / (1-propensity)))

# Run with high weights excluded
lm_ipw <- lm(avg_purch ~ card,
                data = membership_ipw %>% filter(propensity %>% between(0.15, 0.85)),
                weights = ipw)
summ(lm_ipw)






Observations
10000

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
The DAG for the store parking spot example only contains two nodes:

\(D\): Parking spots (Treatment variable)
\(Y\): Sales (Outcome variable)

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
Comparison
Comparing both models, we can see that our model which accounts for subscriptions has a much better accuracy than the one that does not.A coefficient reversal takes place when changing models. For our follow-up only model, the follow-up correlation coefficient is \(R =-3.31\), while it changes to \(R =2.19\) when subscrition model is taken into account.

Follow-up only











Follow-up & Subscrition

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
Explanation
A possible explanation is that the subscription is a confounding factor. Another possible explanation is that the subscription is a collision factor. The most probable explanation is that the subscription is a confounding factor, as the follow-up calls rise and the satisfaction falls with increasing subscription level. Users who use the software the most and the most features (Elite) encounter more problems and need more follow-up calls. This in turn reduces their satisfaction.










Effect of subscription category on satisfaction











Effect of subscription category on follow-up

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text: Not conditioned

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text: Conditioned

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
Task 1
Using the Environement pane in RStudio, we can see that the data has 181 rows and 22 columns.

#> $ cylindernumber   <chr> "four", "four", "six", "four", "five", "five", "five…
#> $ enginesize       <dbl> 130, 130, 152, 109, 136, 136, 136, 136, 131, 131, 10…
#> $ fuelsystem       <chr> "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpf…
#> $ boreratio        <dbl> 3.47, 3.47, 2.68, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.13…
#> $ stroke           <dbl> 2.68, 2.68, 3.47, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40…
#> $ compressionratio <dbl> 9.00, 9.00, 9.00, 10.00, 8.00, 8.50, 8.50, 8.50, 8.3…
#> $ horsepower       <dbl> 111, 111, 154, 102, 115, 110, 110, 110, 140, 160, 10…
#> $ peakrpm          <dbl> 5000, 5000, 5000, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500…
#> $ citympg          <dbl> 21, 21, 19, 24, 18, 19, 19, 19, 17, 16, 23, 23, 21, …
#> $ highwaympg       <dbl> 27, 27, 26, 30, 22, 25, 25, 25, 20, 22, 29, 29, 28, …
#> $ price            <dbl> 13495.00, 16500.00, 16500.00, 13950.00, 17450.00, 15…


Using the glimpse() function form the Pillar package, we can see that all the strings are of type <chr>, while all numeric values are of type <dbl>, which means double precision floating point.


Task 3
Looking at the summary of the linear regression model with the following command

lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices)
summary(lm_all)

we can see that the variable shown below have a significant impact on the car price:

Stroke
Peak RPM
Engine Size
Car width
Car body (hardtop, hatchback, wagon)
Engine location (rear)
Engine type (ohc, ohcv)
Cylinder number (four, five, six, twelve)

Including all the above cited significant variables via the following command:

lm <- lm(price ~ stroke + peakrpm + enginesize + carwidth
          + carbody + enginelocation + enginetype  + cylindernumber,
         data = car_prices)
summary(lm)

we get an adjusted \(R^2 = 0.92\). The previous adjusted \(R^2\) of our model containing all variables was \(R^2 = 0.93\). We lost a bit in prediction accuracy but also reduced the model complexity significantly. A detailed comparison is shwn below:

Task 4
Chosen regressor: enginesize

The engine size is of type <dbl> and can take on values between 61 and 326
The engine size has a positive influence on the price, i.e. a higher engine size, is correlated with a higher car price.
The effect is significant (\(p<0.001\))












Task 5
As we can see below, the OLS method is not able to compute a linear regression coefficient for our newline define variable. This is due to the fact that all out entries for this variable are the same, which results in variance that is exactly equal to \(0\). The OLS method uses the variance of the independent variable as denominator and is therefore not able to determine a corresponding linear regression.

title: Probability Theory
text:
\(P(S) = 0.3\)

\(P(T \mid S) = 0.2\)
\(P(\overline{T} \mid S) = 0.8\)

\(P(\overline{S}) = 0.7\)

\(P(T \mid \overline{S}) = 0.6\)
\(P(\overline{T} \mid \overline{S}) = 0.4\)







\[
\begin{split}
P(T \cap S) = P(S) * P(T \mid S) =0.3*0.2=0.06,\\
P(T \cap \overline{S}) = P(\overline{S}) * P(T \mid \overline{S}) =0.7*0.6=0.42,\\
P(\overline{T} \cap S) = P(S) * P(\overline{T} \mid S) =0.3*0.8=0.24,\\
P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) = P(\overline{S}) * P(\overline{T} \mid \overline{S}) =0.7*0.4=0.28.
\end{split}
\]



\[
P(T \cap S ) + P(T \cap \overline{S}) + P(\overline{T} \cap S) + P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S})
= 1
\]

title: Probability Theory
text:
\(P(S) = 0.3\)

\(P(T \mid S) = 0.2\)
\(P(\overline{T} \mid S) = 0.8\)

\(P(\overline{S}) = 0.7\)

\(P(T \mid \overline{S}) = 0.6\)
\(P(\overline{T} \mid \overline{S}) = 0.4\)

title: Probability Theory
text:
\[
\begin{split}
P(T \cap S) = P(S) * P(T \mid S) =0.3*0.2=0.06,\\
P(T \cap \overline{S}) = P(\overline{S}) * P(T \mid \overline{S}) =0.7*0.6=0.42,\\
P(\overline{T} \cap S) = P(S) * P(\overline{T} \mid S) =0.3*0.8=0.24,\\
P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) = P(\overline{S}) * P(\overline{T} \mid \overline{S}) =0.7*0.4=0.28.
\end{split}
\]



\[
P(T \cap S ) + P(T \cap \overline{S}) + P(\overline{T} \cap S) + P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S})
= 1
\]

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Task 1



Variable
Age
Income




Expected value
33.5
3510.7


Variance
340.6
8.6256458^{6}


Standard deviation
18.5
2936.9





Task 2
Depending on the goal it might make sense to compare both standard deviation relative to their mean, also known as the Coefficient of Variation (CV). This is possible as both variables are absolute and it might inform us of possible data analysis steps we can take. But, in general, it does not really make sense to compare the standard deviation of both distributions directly as they do not have the same unit, i.e. they represent completely different variables.


Task 3

Covariance: 2.97001^{4}
Correlation: 0.55



Task 4
The pearson correlation coefficient is much easier to interpret, as it is a dimensionless value that has a predefined interval \([-1,1]\). This makes it possible to compare the strength of different relationships via the correlation coefficient.
Note: The pearson correlation coefficient is sensitive to outlier and is best used with the assumption of normality. Other correlations, such as Spearman or Kendall, are more robust when the data is not normaly distributed.


Task 5



Age group
[0,18]
[18,65[
[65,\(\infty\)[




\(E[income]\)
391.22
4743.23
1604.19

title: Causality
text:
Below you can see the correlation between the import value of tomatoes in Germany and the number of cosmetic surgeries world wide.














As you can imagine their is no causal link between the two. Nerveless, there is a significant correlation between both variables. The Pearson correlation coefficient is \(R = 0.80\). Both samples are normaly distributed.

title: Causality
text: As you can imagine their is no causal link between the two. Nerveless, there is a significant correlation between both variables. The Pearson correlation coefficient is \(R = 0.80\). Both samples are normaly distributed.

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
Code
#Load data set and libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(jtools)
library(kableExtra)
abtest_online <- readRDS("../../../Causal_Data_Science_Data/abtest_online.rds")

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
Previous site visits
As shown below, we can see that both groups look pretty similar, i.e. balanced with respect to previous site visits.


Code
compare_visits <- 
  ggplot(abtest_online, 
         aes(x = chatbot, 
             y = previous_visit, 
             color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  geom_boxplot(width=0.3, fill="white")+
  stat_boxplot(geom = 'errorbar', width = 0.4)+
  labs(x = "Chatbot acitve", y = "Previous visits", title = 'Previous site visit balance')+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(legend.position = "none")
compare_visits

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
Mobile device usage
As the mobile device usage variable is a boolean, we can only compare the ratio of mobile device across both groups. Again, both groups seem balanced.


Code
#Calculate mobile device usage for each group
mbu_aggregate=aggregate(abtest_online$mobile_device,by=list(abtest_online$chatbot),FUN=mean)
names(mbu_aggregate)<-c('chatbot', 'mobile_device')

compare_device <- 
  ggplot(mbu_aggregate, 
         aes(x = chatbot, 
             y = mobile_device, 
             color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  geom_boxplot(width=0.3, fill="white")+
  labs(x = "Chatbot acitve", y = "Previous visits", title = 'Mobile device usage balance')+
  ylim(0,1)+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(legend.position = "none")
compare_device
